posts.name: Xashyar
posts.cooked:
• Recommended here as the “Best Privacy Chat App”:
Privacy Heroes

Privacy Heroes

We're an alliance of privacy-focused online services on a mission to defend Internet users from surveillance, hacking, and censorship.

  • Listed as #3 in Social Networking (Paid) on the App Store

  • +1M installs on Google Play

  • Somehow Open Source:

GitHub

Threema GmbH

Seriously Secure Messaging. Threema GmbH has 15 repositories available. Follow their code on GitHub.

Given that there are free, more transparent alternatives (not to mention Signal :D (or Wire)) it seems to be growing at an astonishing rate.

So I was wondering what sort of Unique capabilities it offers in general and more specifically compared with Signal in terms of UX?

Slightly discussed here: Comparison of encrypted messengers - #2 by 5_c_d

Identity is not tied to a phone number but a “randomly generated, 8-digit Threema ID when starting the app for the first time. This ID is your unique address in Threema and makes it possible to use Threema completely anonymously, without disclosing any personal information” (source)

They also have an open-source web interface (What’s the difference between desktop app and web client? – Threema)

A general feature set can be found at What features does Threema offer?, including Threema Safe which allows you to make an encrypted backup of some of your metadata (What is Threema Safe and how do I enable it?) and you can store this on their server or your own server

link_counts.title: What features does Threema offer? - Threema
What is a Threema ID? - Threema

posts.name: Xashyar
posts.cooked:
reality:

They also have an open-source web interface (What’s the difference between desktop app and web client? – Threema)

It sorta works like Whatsapp Web, and can not be accessed independently.

reality:

A general feature set can be found at What features does Threema offer?, including Threema Safe which allows you to make an encrypted backup of some of your metadata (What is Threema Safe and how do I enable it?) and you can store this on their server or your own server

I’ve previously checked their their Crypto Whitepaper but I’m mostly looking for people who have tried it or use it on a regular basis share their UX.
So there’s nothing significant other than anonymity as compared to Signal?

They hit WhatsApp in time to market with encryption. WhatsApp introduced encryption around 6 month later, if I remember correctly.

They were (and are) also very clearly perceived as “European app”.

Both was enough to get them a fan base and network effects that seems to be very sustainable.

Xashyar:

Recommended here as the “Best Privacy Chat App”

This isn’t a real recommendation. “Privacy Heroes” is an alliance consisting of devs of privacy-focused software, and Threema is part of this alliance.

Xashyar:

So I was wondering what sort of Unique capabilities it offers in general and more specifically compared with Signal in terms of UX?

  1. No phone number but a generated ID, which optionally can get linked to the phone number and/or an email address
  2. They’re based in Switzerland, which has a good reputation regarding privacy
  3. Imho, their UI is exceptionally clean and intuitive, and their setup assistant is top-notch
  4. Most importantly, Threema got recommended in 2014 as the messenger with the best privacy by the German Stiftung Warentest back then. Since Stiftung Warentest has an excellent reputation in Germany and their recommendation got a lot of press in Germany’s media, this had a huge impact, especially at the time of the Snowden relevations, and many people installed Threema (only to switch back to WhatsApp later on, as they became aware that only a small fraction of their contacts had made the move to Threema). In a later 2015 messenger review, Stiftung Warentest changed their No. 1 recommendation to Hoccer, though, a messenger I strangely had never heard of prior to their recommendation.
  5. All that said, I’m a long-time user of both Signal and Threema. I like them both, and they are the only messengers installed on my phone

link_counts.title: Messenger-Apps - Ein Außenseiter schlägt WhatsApp & Co - Stiftung Warentest
WhatsApp und Alternativen - Datenschutz im Test - Stiftung Warentest

posts.cooked: It is interesting that on privacytools.io there is a statement “If you are currently using an Instant Messenger like WhatsApp, Viber, LINE, Telegram or Threema, you should pick an alternative here.” and then Signal is listed as best candidate. From the list of 5, Thereema is the most trusted, it looks that it doesn’t belong to this group of messengers, specially because there is no Facebook Messenger and Skype on the list. It would be nice to know why they pick Threema as not recommended to use.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
RiseT:

o. 1 recommendation to Hoccer , though, a messenger I strangely had never heard of prior to their recommendation.

This is also the first time I hear from it. However, they state: " All Hoccer servers are located in Germany and are therefore, subject to the German data protection law." If Seehofer gets it his way that is not really a recommendation.
Personally I think Wickr Me is better than Threema and is like Signal plus has a few extra handy features that Signal doesn’t have, but both apps are great

shellSignal:

It would be nice to know why they pick Threema as not recommended to use.

There are only two drawbacks that I know of:

  • Only partially open source
  • No perfect forward secrecy in their crypto
  • Perhaps one could add missing disappearing messages, but that’s not that important imho

But overall, Threema doesn’t belong into that list, and I have no idea why it’s in there.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
RiseT:

and I have no idea why it’s in there.

Maybe because it managed to become popular in some professions where Signals lack of central administration and group management is considered unacceptable, like medical communication. Threema has a version for companies: https://work.threema.ch/

shellSignal:

WhatsApp, Viber, LINE, Telegram

What I mean is that Threema doesn’t belong into the “WhatsApp, Viber, LINE” list.

The end-to-end encryption of Threema does not offer forward secrecy; so it’s a bit old fashioned. Signal and WhatsApp offer more modern encryption.

The advantage of Threema is anonymity, which you CAN have using Threema, but only if you chose so not to connect phone number or email with your Threema ID.

Most people using Threema don’t care about anonymity though and believe the encryption is superior, which it isn’t.

Xashyar:

So there’s nothing significant other than anonymity as compared to Signal?

That’s the main draw. See also: Registering with an email address perennial request. Of course, you have to pay for threema, and most people are not capable of truly anonymizing their payment-details – Threema offers pseudonymity only, methinks. With signalapp you have to pay for a telco-num, and this is very difficult to do truly anonymously as well, so for advanced folks it is a “tie” sorta… depends on whether you want to shield your threema-identity from your contacts or from powerful adversaries, if they former then threema is a win, if the latter, probably not a win.

They are headquartered in Germany and devs live in EU, which means they are GDPR-compliant by law (situation for signalapp is unclear/unknown) cf Encrypted backup violates GDPR's right to data portability and Europe implements GDPR in may 2018 and Data Protection v3 for discussion. Servers are hosted in Switzerland, which might make Threema somehow immune to German politicians? So they claim, at least e.g. German Secretary of Interior: To all messengers! End E2EE or get banned (but see also German Attorney General will force Signal to be interoperable with FB Messenger related)

RiseT:

only a small fraction of their contacts had made the move to Threema

This is the primary downside. It is a paid app. You will never, never, never convince most people to pay for pseudo-anonymity, any more than you can get them to pay for privacy. If you are starting a new group of 9 people, one of them will balk. If you are trying to form a new group of 99 people, several of them will balk. Even getting people to install signalapp is tough, and it is run by a non-profit and costs nothing!

So although threema is going to be a competitor to things like SilentPhone and things like CopperheadOS and things like WireappPro, where the target is the corporate market and the boss can pay the bills and then make all employees install, even the boss cannot insist that customers of the firm install and pay for threema. Niche, forever.

Because they ARE a paid proprietary software product, they have a nice UI, and because they are a privacy-oriented firm, they might be better than whatsapp? But they are still a profit-oriented firm, just, they want to monetize subscriptions, not monetize via adverts. There is no way to fork threema, if they decide to alter their business-model, or sell themselves to a bigger corporation (as happened to whatsapp).

shellSignal:

It would be nice to know why they pick Threema as not recommended to use.

Although there is no prohibition against non-libre-licensed products on privacyToolsIO there is a strong preference (ability to audit the entire codebase) for recommending libre-licensed projects whenever that is possible. Signalapp is 100% GPLv3 client-side and 100% AGPLv3 server-side, more popular than Threema, more well-vetted crypto than threema, and so on… thus, it gets the top recommendation, and threema is not even listed.

You can see a similar dynamic in the VPN listings at privacyToolsIO – they don’t even list TunnelBear by McAfee, because there are a lot of other VPNs out there not in five-eyes countries. Signalapp is in a FiveEyes country, TheOneBigEyeball in fact, but privacyToolsIO makes an exception because it is still the best option.

The people running privacyToolsIO are not making perfect recommendations, but they are making really good ones, that I have seen. They don’t list threema because it costs money and because it is not libre-licensed, AND because there are options just as easy-to-use and just as popular-in-terms-of-network-effect which are free-as-in-freedom

e.g. here is a mention of threema and some product by spideroak, which was closed back in 2016 by a maintainer == https://github.com/privacytoolsIO/privacytools.io/issues/129 …they are not purists about decentralization, and not purists about libre-licensing, but when available they prefer both.

posts.cooked:
RiseT:

WhatsApp, Viber, LINE, Telegram

What I mean is that Threema doesn’t belong into the “WhatsApp, Viber, LINE” list.

I agree. There should be a list of privacy problematic messengers: Facebook Messenger, WhatsApp, Viber, LINE, Skype,… and a list of privacy messengers:
Signal, Thereema, Wire, Wickr me. Inside privacy messengers we can discuss which is better etc.

Janine:

Most people using Threema don’t care about anonymity though and believe the encryption is superior, which it isn’t.

User needs to use right tool for right purpose. Threema if anonymity is important. Signal if security/privacy is main concern.

You can use signalapp with a modicum of anonymity, but you have to acquire a phone-num that is not tied to your identity. If you are just trying to shield your identity from a contact or two on a temporary basis, you can get a secondary-num that you don’t tell most people (e.g. googleVoice or twitterSms or whatever). If you need a longer-term solution that is applicable against all but the most powerful nationstate adversaries, you can purchase a voip-num with monero, or a burner-number in a cash or barter-transaction.

These are very difficult and painful, which is why I think we want nikNums eventually, not to eliminate the phone-num during registration, but to shield Alice’s telco-num during use of signalapp.

shellSignal:

There should be a list of privacy problematic messengers

Well, you can propose a change on the privacyToolsIO github, or one of their other places (they have a discourse forum like signalUsers except self-hosted rather than outsourced and they have a mastodon page and a bunch of stuff like that). Maybe it will get removed from the list-of-shame, or at least, listed in a second sentence: “Although these messengers are not anti-privacy, they are proprietary code and cost money: Threema, SilentPhone, etc” Pull requests · privacytoolsIO/privacy-tools · GitHub and click [New Issue] button, then create a “Discussion: Threema” if you like

But like has been mentioned above, in addition to be proprietary code (hurts auditability and long-term viability), and in addition to costing money to use (immediately hurts the anonymity-claim), and in addition to having a small userbase (about one seventh of signalapp roughly), Threema has some “real” downsides: no disappearing messages which is critical for e.g. political use-cases, lack of perfect forward secrecy (they have “session secrecy” whatever that is… TLS wrapper?). More detailed comparison here in the ‘over 9000’ collapse-block … threema is better than wickrMe, sorry @DarkHorse :-) … but signalapp is way better, and with care the savvy enduser can get a secondary num to provide a degree of anonymity with Signal

link_counts.title: A proposal for alternative primary identifiers
A proposal for alternative primary identifiers

posts.cooked:
The only thing I want from Threema is the option to be assigned a Signal number instead of using my actual phone number as my ID.

Until this happens, Signal will not be fully utilized by people who care about their privacy because anonymity is linked to privacy.

shellSignal:

User needs to use right tool for right purpose. Threema if anonymity is important. Signal if security/privacy is main concern

Yes but it is important to understand, that this kind of trade-off is not necessary.
Threema could improve their encryption and use a protocol with forward secrecy like Signal, Wire or Wickr do.

And Signal could - if they wanted - skip the phone numbers and use something like “Signal IDs”.

Although I doubt that any of this is going to happen during the next time, this approach is possible.

Halcyon:

anonymity is linked to privacy

It depends who you contact. If you are whisperer and want to contact journalist about corrupted politician anonymity is vitally important, but if you contact your friends then you reveal your phone number to your friend that already knows your phone number. In this case anonymity is basted right away.

Signal was never marketing itself to be anonymity tool, it market itself to fight massive surveillance.

Janine:

Signal could - if they wanted - skip the phone numbers and use something like “Signal IDs”.

Sure Signal could do this. Or user can do himself/herself by getting phone number from different sources like @5_c_d has written above. Yes, this is annoying, but still possible.

Janine:

Threema could improve their encryption and use a protocol with forward secrecy

This is true, and would be helpful. But no matter how improved their protocol is, it will not be as well-vetted and field-hardened as Signal Protocol, until and unless Threema starts using Signal Protocol internally (like Whatsapp / off-by-default Skype / etc).

Janine:

Signal could - if they wanted - skip the phone numbers and use something like “Signal IDs”.

Well, it is not a question of wanting to or not wanting to. There are 2 big blockers:

  1. plenty of endusers have trouble remembering their OWN phone-num. If you give them a Signal-ID which is not their telco-num, what happens when they forget it? Can they ask for it back, somehow? Related: Won’t we need a password associated with each Signal-ID? what if you forget that? What if you used 1234 as your password? If you lose your handset, you can re-register your signal-num, because you still control your telco-num, right? How do you recover control of a Signal-ID?

  2. what happens when a wholesale-spammer signs up for six quadrillion Signal-IDs and starts selling them to retail-spammers at ten-thousand-for-a-dollar? We cannot block spam with server-side message-body scanning like gmail, signal-server cannot even see who the sender is, most of the time, let alone what the message contains (at any time!). Signal-server does not constantly spy on who contacts whom, when, and in what way… and all IPs and other network-level stuff is deleted from RAM as soon as possible on signal-server as well… so we cannot even do the simpler protonmail kind of anti-spam (they “cannot” see message-bodies but can see subject-line from-line to-line IP-addr etc for every protonmail message which is enough for SpamAssassin). If spam ever takes hold in signal-network, it will be the death-knell of the usefulness of signalapp, so we HAVE to prevent it. Spammers don’t like paying for telco-nums, they are pricey versus e.g. email addresses.

There are also a lot of usability-problems that “just go away” when the person has a signal-num which matches their telco-num, not least of which is contact-discovery, addressbook-integration, and so on. Any kind of non-telco-num-based Signal-ID would ideally be compatible with addressbook-apps (Threema identifiers are not methinks)

Xashyar:

So there’s nothing significant other than anonymity as compared to Signal?

Way better UI, better and more functions, better group-management, Switzerland-based.
